channel.title: Managing Players: Array Or List?

item.title: Managing Players: Array Or List?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:29, topic:427888”][quote author=t4 link=topic=530579.msg3875766#msg3875766 date=1325659976]

Would this List, not accept nulls?

[code=java]import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger;
import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicReferenceArray;

public class RS2List {

private AtomicReferenceArray<T> list;
private int maxIndex;
private AtomicInteger pointerIndex;

public RS2List(int size) {
	maxIndex = size + 1;
	pointerIndex = new AtomicInteger(1);
	list = new AtomicReferenceArray<T>(maxIndex);
}

public T get(int index) {
	return list.get(index);
}

public int length() {
	return list.length();
}

public void set(int index, T object) {
	list.set(index, object);
}

public void remove(int index) {
	list.set(index, null);
	pointerIndex.set(index);
}

public int returnIndex() {
	int pointedIndex = pointerIndex.get();
	if (get(pointedIndex) == null)
		return pointedIndex;
}

}[/code]

Thanks for comments guys.

Do you understand what NULL is? Or how an ArrayList works?
[/quote]
Yes, and partially. Why?[/quote]
Because NULL is just what a reference gets assigned to when it has no value; what you posted is a thread-safe ArrayList - which if you look at the implementation, it has an underlying array to store the data.

Read full topic

item.title: Managing Players: Array Or List?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:27, topic:427888”]@t4: Do you know the performance difference between storing the next available slot as an Integer, and finding the next slot with a loop? I would think that the overhead from boxing the Integer would make a noticable difference as the stack size increased.

Although, depending on the underlying specifications of the computer, it may/not be an improvement. If the machine has high CPU and low RAM, then using a for-loop would be more efficient, whereas if the machine has low CPU and high RAM, then it would definitely be an increase.[/quote]
I haven’t done any benchmarks, but one would think storing an integer of all things in a LinkedList would be far better than performing an O(N) operation every time a player logs in. Also, with mine you keep track of the used positions in the array - meaning that you do a smaller iteration when updating.

Also, the memory usage should be constant for the two stacks. s1 + s2 should always = sizeof(plrArray)

PSS: stack object != JVM stack, all objects are created on the heap.

Read full topic

item.title: Managing Players: Array Or List?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

@t4: Do you know the performance difference between storing the next available slot as an Integer, and finding the next slot with a loop? I would think that the overhead from boxing the Integer would make a noticable difference as the stack size increased.

Although, depending on the underlying specifications of the computer, it may/not be an improvement. If the machine has high CPU and low RAM, then using a for-loop would be more efficient, whereas if the machine has low CPU and high RAM, then it would definitely be an increase.

Read full topic

item.title: Managing Players: Array Or List?
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:22, topic:427888”][quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=530579.msg3874983#msg3874983 date=1325615698]

I’m going to assume he meant using your method to generate the unique id then putting it into the map t4, otherwise his method wouldnt work at all (where would the integer key come from?)

It would be the player id given. this is based off pi… soo… u can see where im coming from

		//lil test..
		player.put(slot, client1);
		player.get(slot).isActive = true;
		player.get(slot).connectedFrom = ((InetSocketAddress) client1.getSession()
				.getRemoteAddress()).getAddress().getHostAddress();

What is the value of slot, how is it determined?

		int slot = -1;
		for (int i = 1; i < Config.MAX_PLAYERS; i++) {
			if ((players[i] == null) || players[i].disconnected) {
				slot = i;
				break;
			}
		}
		if (slot == -1)
			return false;

The map was just a test at a shot for efficiency. I still haven’t converted to maps completely cause I got caught up with everything else… this player id was based off the playerhandler array atm
[/quote]
You’ll find your solution is flawed/doesn’t work or is highly inefficient.[/quote]
Ye ik. This was a month ago. I learn a lot everyday. In my current project, I see how it’s storing the players and understand it’s much more efficient than PI’s way.

Read full topic

item.title: Managing Players: Array Or List?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:14, topic:427888”][quote author=t4 link=topic=530579.msg3874952#msg3874952 date=1325614433]

You want to use a simple array with a stack of the ‘used’ and ‘unused’ indices. This way you have O(1) operations for: finding a spot to place a new player and accessing an existing player, and removing an existing player. The time for the update operation (which traditionally iterates through the entire player array) is now massively cut down; you would only visit the indices provided in the ‘used’ stack.

More info here:
https://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php?topic=510805.0

oh forgot about that.

Couldn’t you just use a concurrent map?

To hold what?
[/quote]
The player id and the player object

[code=java]
public static Map<Integer, Player> player = new HashMap<Integer, Player>();

public static Map<Integer, Player> getPlayer() {
	return player;
}

[/code][/quote]
Your code is wrong, but the problem with that is how does one generate a unique Id. You see, for example, the rs2 client sends for it’s attacking packet the user Id of the player being attacked (the user Id being the index of the player entity within the array). Furthermore, Maps are expensive - especially when a lot of entries are put into them. Also, every time the Map’s underlying array runs out of space, the array must be copied (Very (well unnecessarily) expensive CPU and memory wise). I could think of more, but meh.

Read full topic
